questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common benign lesion of liver?
questions.explanation:
Hemangiomas are the most common benign tumor of the liver. Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is the second most common benign tumor of the liver. 707 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is not true about epithelioid hemangioma?

options.a: Exposure to vinyl chloride is a risk factor
options.b: Treatment of choice is liver transplantation
options.c: Factor VIII staining is used for diagnosis

questions.explanation:
Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma is more common in females. Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma is a rare vascular tumour. The infantile variety is benign, 
while the adult variety is malignant. It may undergo malignant degeneration into angiosarcoma. It is related to exposure to vinyl chloride and oral contraceptive pills (OCPs). It can affect the lungs, liver, and bones. In the liver, it manifests as multiple bilateral hepatic 
masses. Extrahepatic metastases occur in approximately 25% of patients. Liver failure is a fatal 
complication. Hypervascular enhancement is observed on CECT. A percutaneous biopsy can help differentiate 
from other tumours. Factor VIII staining differentiates it from other nonvascular tumours. Treatment is total hepatectomy with liver transplantation.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 45-year-old woman was incidentally found to have a lesion in the right lobe of the liver 
during an abdominal ultrasound. CECT showed the following finding. What is the most likely 
diagnosis? 702 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given CECT abdomen shows a well-defined hypodense lesion in the liver with asymmetrical 
nodular peripheral enhancement which is characteristic of hemangioma. Hemangioma is a benign tumor composed of increased proliferation of blood vessels. It is the 
most common benign tumour of the liver and is mainly seen in women at a mean age of 45 years. Small capillary hemangiomas are of no clinical significance. They are usually solitary, <5 cm in 
diameter, with equal occurrence in the right and left halves of the liver. However, giant 
hemangiomas of diameter >5 cm require attention. They are most commonly asymptomatic and incidentally found during imaging studies. Large 
compressive masses may cause vague upper abdominal symptoms. The appearance of hepatic 
hemangioma in a contrast-enhanced CT scan is as follows: • Non-contrast phase: Well-defined hypodense lesion • Arterial phase: Peripheral nodular enhancement • Washout phase: Homogenous enhancement The image given below shows early phase with peripheral high attenuation (a) and late phase with 
homogenous high attenuation (b). 708 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following hepatic lesions can be accurately diagnosed with 99mTc-labelled red 
blood cells when CT and MRI are unavailable?
questions.explanation:
Hemangiomas can be accurately diagnosed with 99mTc-labelled red cells when CT and MRI are 
unavailable. In hemangioma, an increase in uptake is observed in blood pool studies such as 99mTc-labelled 
red cells and appear as photopenic regions. The nuclear imaging techniques for the diagnosis of 
hemangiomas are used only when high-quality CT and MRI are unavailable. CECT is the investigation of choice wherein a typical peripheral nodular enhancement pattern is 
seen. On magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), hemangiomas are hypointense on T1-weighted images and 
hyperintense on T2-weighted images. The below MRI image shows the light bulb sign seen in hemangioma of the liver. 709 
Sold by @itachibot Percutaneous biopsy is potentially dangerous and inaccurate and, therefore, not recommended. Isotope scans used for the investigation of hepatobiliary disease are: • Technetium-99m colloid scan - parenchymal diseases of the liver, such as cirrhosis and alcoholic 
hepatitis • Technetium-99m hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan - acute cholecystitis and 
congenital biliary atresia • Technetium-99m sulphur colloid scan - focal nodular hyperplasia

questions.question:
Question 5: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the ER with complaints of petechiae, bruising, and abdominal 
distension as shown in the image. Investigations reveal thrombocytopenia and elevated 
D-dimer. CECT shows solitary growth in the liver with peripheral nodular enhancement. 
Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition? 703 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Kasai procedure is done for symptomatic cases
options.c: LFT and tumour markers are normal

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kasabach-Merritt syndrome because of hemangioma of 
the liver. Kasai procedure or hepatoportoenterostomy is done for biliary atresia, and not 
in Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. Rarely a rapidly enlarging hemangioma can cause thrombocytopenia and disseminated 
intravascular coagulation (indicated by the elevated D-dimer) because platelets and other clotting 
factors are being used up within the tumour. This is called Kasabach-Merritt syndrome. LFT and tumour markers are normal in a hemangioma. Large hemangiomas in children can result 
in congestive heart failure secondary to arteriovenous shunting and they require medical 
management. Management: Observation is the mode of management in asymptomatic liver hemangiomas that are <5cm 
because they may show spontaneous regression. Therapeutic embolisation and enucleation with arterial inflow control is the treatment of choice 
for patients with symptomatic liver hemangiomas.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 32-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain and discomfort for the past 2 months. 
She has been using oral contraceptive pills for more than 5 years. Imaging studies revealed a 
mass as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: Rupture and intraperitoneal hemorrhage is unlikely
options.b: Malignant transformation is seen in 10% of cases
options.c: Histology shows cords of hepatocytes with absence of bile ductules

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and MRI showing homogeneous mass with well-defined margins is 
suggestive of hepatic adenoma. Rupture leading to life-threatening intraperitoneal hemorrhage is 
a major complication associated with hepatic adenomas. Hepatic adenomas are benign solid neoplasms of the liver. They are usually seen in young women 
between 20-40 years of age and are typically solitary. Prolonged oral contraceptive use is a clear 
risk factor. Clinical presentation may be abdominal pain. Histological studies show cords of benign hepatocytes containing excessive glycogen and fat, 
giving a congested or vacuolated appearance. There is an absence of bile duct glands and Kupffer 
cells. In some patients, hepatic adenomas present with spontaneous intraperitoneal hemorrhage. There 
is a risk of malignant transformation in 10% of cases. 710 
Sold by @itachibot The histopathological image given below shows hepatic adenoma.

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following types of hepatic adenomas is associated with an increased risk of 
malignant transformation?
questions.explanation:
-catenin mutated subtype of hepatic adenoma is associated with an increased risk of malignant 
transformation. The 2017 Bordeaux molecular-pathologic classification of hepatocellular adenomas (HCA) 
includes six subtypes: • HNF1A-inactivated HCA • Inflammatory HCA • -catenin exon 3 mutated HCA • -catenin exon 7/8 mutated HCA • Sonic hedgehog activated HCA • Unclassified HCA

questions.question:
Question 8: During USG in a 30-year-old bodybuilder on anabolic steroids, a liver mass was noted. The 
surgeon suspects hepatic adenoma. Which of the following is false regarding investigations 
performed for this condition?

options.b: Imaging shows a well circumscribed vascular tumor
options.c: Resection and biopsy are done when other investigations are equivocal
options.d: MRI with gadobenate dimeglumine as contrast helps to distinguish from other tumors

questions.explanation:
AFP levels are usually within the normal range in hepatic adenoma. In this patient, the use of anabolic steroids is a risk factor for developing hepatic adenoma. Computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) demonstrates a 
well-circumscribed and vascular solid tumor. Arterial phase CT demonstrates a well-developed 
peripheral arterialization of a tumor. Dynamic magnetic resonance imaging with liver-specific MRI contrast agents such as gadobenate 
dimeglumine helps to better distinguish hepatic adenomas from follicular nodular hyperplasia by 711 
Sold by @itachibot their enhancement characteristics during the hepatobiliary phase of imaging. A biopsy may be necessary for the confirmation and characterization of the nature of these lesions 
when imaging studies are equivocal.

questions.question:
Question 9: Spontaneous rupture of the liver occurs in  
.
questions.explanation:
Hepatic adenoma can manifest as a case of spontaneous rupture, with the sudden onset of 
abdominal pain followed by hypovolemic shock secondary to intraperitoneal bleeding. The clinical presentation may be abdominal pain. In some cases, it can hepatic adenomas present 
with spontaneous intraperitoneal hemorrhage.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which statement regarding the management of hepatic adenoma is false? 705 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: MRI surveillance is done for 5 years
options.b: Hepatic artery embolization is done in cases of hemorrhage
options.c: In women, the risk of malignant transformation is low if tumour <10 cm
options.d: In men, resection is done independent of the tumour size

questions.explanation:
In women, the risk of malignant transformation is low if tumour <5 cm. Due to the high risk of malignancy in males, hepatic adenomas should be resected independent of 
the tumour size or subtype of the lesion. In female patients, conservative management with discontinuation of oral contraceptive pills and 
MRI surveillance is recommended if the tumour is <5 cm in 
diameter. Either annual (non-inflammatory adenoma) or biannual (inflammatory hepatocellular 
adenoma) MRI surveillance is done for at least 5 years, depending on the tumour subtype. If the tumour is >5 cm, resection is done. In patients presenting with acute hemorrhage, 
hepatic artery embolization is done to prevent further hemorrhage till the patient can be taken up 
for resection of the tumour.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following statements are false regarding focal nodular hyperplasia?

options.a: Resection is done for persistent symptomatic cases
options.c: Appears as hotspots in Tc 99m sulphur colloid scan

questions.explanation:
Malignant transformation is unlikely in focal nodular hyperplasia. Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for FNH. It is seen as a well-circumscribed lesion with a 
typical central scar. They show intense homogeneous enhancement on the arterial phase and 
isodense as compared to the background liver on the venous phase. Due to the presence of Kupffer cells, FNH appears as hotspots on Tc 99m sulphur colloid scans. Asymptomatic patients with typical radiologic features do not require treatment. Careful 
observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a 
significant number of cases. Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for 
resection. If diagnostic uncertainty exists, resection may be necessary for histologic confirmation. 712 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 27-year-old woman was incidentally found to have a liver mass while undergoing 
ultrasound for renal calculi. CECT showed the following image. What is the most probable 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario with contrast-enhanced CT showing hypervascular lesion with a 
central non-enhancing scar points towards focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). Focal nodular hyperplasia is the second most common benign tumour in the liver and is mostly 
seen in women. This condition is characterised by focal overgrowth of functional liver tissue and 
the supporting fibrous stroma. Patients are mostly asymptomatic and FNH is often an incidental finding. If patients are 
symptomatic, they usually complain of abdominal pain. On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary 
epithelium scattered throughout. A central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in 
a spoke-wheel pattern is also seen.
